description:
The planner is responsible for taking the tokens extracted from the query string by the Parser; and converting them into a Logical Query Plan
[URL#1](https://planetscale.com/blog/what-is-a-query-planner); [URL#2](https://blog.mireo.com/from-a-string-to-the-thing-parsing-and-planning-sql-queries-with-apache-calcite-part-1)

To get efficient query plans; one needs dynamic-programming-based query optimization; informed by good statistics: typically a combination of table samples (that allow to detect correlated predicates within a table) and hyperloglogs on most data to estimate distinct counts [17](https://db.in.tum.de/~freitag/papers/p29-neumann-cidr20.pdf). [URL#1](https://dione.lib.unipi.gr/xmlui/bitstream/handle/unipi/15010/Query%20Optimization%20with%20Deep%20Learning%20Architectures.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y)
Doris: [CBO (join reorder) & RBO (constant folding; subquery rewriting; predicate pushdown](https://medium.com/@ApacheDoris/introduction-to-apache-doris-incubating-48aaa1df34ae)

Oracle: Index unique scan; index range scan; index full scan; index fast full scan; table access by index rowid; table access full
MySQL: Eq_ref; ref; index; all; using index
PostgreSQL: Seq scan; index scan; index only scan; bitmap scan; TID scan

Oracle: Nested loop joins; hash join; merge join
PostgreSQL: Nested loops; hash join; merge join

Oracle: Sort order by; sort order by stopkey; sort group by; sort group by nosort; hash group by

description: The transaction manager manages all currently open transactions; and is in charge of handling COMMIT or ROLLBACK commands.
